revision.text:
{{More citations needed|date=August 2009}} {{Infobox university |name = King Fahd University of Petroleum & Minerals
{{lang|ar|جامعة الملك فهد للبترول و المعادن}}
{{transl|ar|DIN|''Jāmiʿat al-Malik Fahd li-l-Bitrūl wa-l-Maʿādin''}} |image = King Fahd University of Petroleum & Minerals Logo.svg |image_size = 200px |caption = KFUPM Logo |motto = {{lang|ar|وقل رب زدني علما}}
{{transl|ar|DIN|''Wa-Qul Rabb-ī Zid-nī ʿIlman''}}
Say, 'Lord increase my knowledge' |established = {{start date and age|1963|9|23|df=yes}} |former_names = College of Petroleum and Minerals (1963–1975)
University of Petroleum and Minerals (1975–1986)
King Fahd University of Petroleum and Minerals{{cite web|title=History|url=http://www.kfupm.edu.sa/SitePages/en/DetailPage.aspx?CUSTOMID=2&LinkID=Link24|publisher=KFUPM|accessdate=8 June 2012}}(1986-Now) |type = [[Public university|Public]] |Acting rector = [[Prof. Dr. Sahel N. Abduljauwad]] |city = [[Dhahran]] |province = [[Eastern Province, Saudi Arabia|Eastern Province]] |country = [[Saudi Arabia]] |undergrad = 8,000+ |postgrad = 1500+ |faculty = 800+ |campus = Enclosed |nickname = ''{{transl|ar|DIN|Jāmiʿat al-Bitrūl}}'' |website = [http://www.kfupm.edu.sa/ www.kfupm.edu.sa] |endowment = more than $500 million}} '''King Fahd University of Petroleum and Minerals''' ('''KFUPM''' or '''UPM''') ({{lang-ar|جامعة الملك فهد للبترول و المعادن}}, {{transl|ar|DIN|''Jāmiʿat al-Malik Fahd li-l-Bitrūl wa-l-Maʿādin''}} – short: {{lang-ar|جامعة البترول}} {{transl|ar|DIN|''Jāmiʿat al-Bitrūl''}}) is a [[public university]] in [[Dhahran]], Saudi Arabia. Among [[List of universities and colleges in Saudi Arabia|Saudi universities]], its science and engineering programs are highly regarded.{{cite web|title=Academic Ranking of World Universities in Mathematics – 2012|url=http://www.shanghairanking.com/SubjectMathematics2012.html|publisher=ShanghaiRanking Consultancy|accessdate=23 September 2012}} ==History== KFUPM was established on 23 September 1963 by a Saudi royal [[decree]] as the '''College of Petroleum and Minerals''' providing high-level education about petroleum and minerals, two of the most-valuable [[natural resources]] in Saudi Arabia. It was elevated to university status in 1975. It was renamed after [[Fahd of Saudi Arabia|King Fahd]] in 1986. ==Academics== KFUPM offers degrees of Bachelor of Science, [[Master of Science]], [[Master of Engineering]] and Doctor of Philosophy. The grading system is the standard 0 to 4.0 scale with classes of:{{Citation needed|date=December 2017}} {|class="wikitable" |- !Grade !Letter Grade !GPA |- !Exceptional |A+ |4.00 |- !Excellent |A |3.75 |- !Superior |B+ |3.50 |- !Very Good |B |3.00 |- !Above Average |C+ |2.50 |- !Good |C |2.00 |- !High-Pass |D+ |1.50 |- !Pass |D |1.00 |- !Fail |F |0.0 |- |} ===Admissions=== With an acceptance rate of only 10%, it is the most selective in Saudi Arabia. The university's admission policy applies certain criteria to ensure admissions of the most promising students.{{cite web|url=http://www2.kfupm.edu.sa/admissions/Files/AdmissionsRules.htm |title=معايير القبول في الجامعة |publisher=King Fahd University|accessdate=11 August 2012}} In 2012, the university accepted the best 2% of high school graduates from all over the Kingdom.{{Cite news|last=المانع|first=عبدالله|title=السلطان: جامعة البترول استقطبت أفضل 02% من طلاب المملكة|url=http://www.al-madina.com/node/398394|accessdate=24 September 2012|newspaper=Al Madina|date=1 September 2012}} comprising 20% for the high school certificate, 30% for the general capabilities test (similar to [[SAT]]), and 50% for the collective test performances (test of high school's maths, physics, chemistry and Biology). Both the general capabilities test and the collective test are constructed by [[Qiyas Tests|Qiyas]]. === Rankings === KFUPM was named the top university in the Arab Region as per QS University Rankings for 2015{{Cite web|url=http://www.topuniversities.com/university-rankings/arab-region-university-rankings/2015#sorting=rank+region=+country=+faculty=+stars=false+search=|title=QS University Rankings: Arab Region 2015|date=2015-05-28|access-date=2016-10-02}} and 2016.{{Cite web|url=http://www.topuniversities.com/university-rankings/arab-region-university-rankings/2016#sorting=rank+region=+country=+faculty=+stars=false+search=|title=QS University Rankings: Arab Region 2016|date=2016-06-08|access-date=2016-10-02}} KFUPM was ranked '''18''' among "QS Top 50 Under 50".{{cite web|url=http://www.topuniversities.com/university-rankings/top-50-under-50|title=QS Top 50 under 50|publisher=Top Universities|accessdate=11 August 2012}} The ''QS Top 50 Under 50'' is a new ranking that lists the leading universities worldwide founded since 1962.{{cite web|url=http://www.topuniversities.com/university-rankings/qs-top-50-under-50|title=QS Top 50 Under 50|publisher=Top Universities|accessdate=11 August 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120820161023/http://www.topuniversities.com/university-rankings/qs-top-50-under-50|archivedate=20 August 2012|df=dmy-all}} Also, it was ranked as one of the best 400 universities around the world according to the Academic Ranking of World Universities [[ARWU]] in 2011 and 2012 by [[Shanghai Jiaotong University]].{{cite web|title=King Fahd University of Petroleum & Minerals|url=http://www.shanghairanking.com/Institution.jsp?param=King%20Fahd%20University%20of%20Petroleum%20&%20Minerals|publisher=Shanghai Ranking Consultancy|accessdate=23 September 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120629025041/http://www.shanghairanking.com/Institution.jsp?param=King%20Fahd%20University%20of%20Petroleum%20&%20Minerals|archivedate=29 June 2012|df=dmy-all}} In 2012, the [[ARWU]] ranked the Mathematics subject in top 50 worldwide. In the academic year 2013-2014, it was awarded the 216th position in the QS World University Rankings.{{cite news|title=KFUPM ranks 216th in world university rankings|url=http://www.arabnews.com/news/464897|accessdate=14 February 2014|newspaper=Arab News|date=17 September 2013}} ===Accreditation=== All programs of the engineering colleges were evaluated for "[[Substantial equivalence|Substantial-Equivalency]]" recognition by the [[Accreditation Board for Engineering and Technology]] (ABET).[http://www.abet.org/AccredProgramSearch/AccreditationSearch.aspx] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110817205746/http://www.abet.org/AccredProgramSearch/AccreditationSearch.aspx |date=17 August 2011 }} They were found substantially equivalent to similar accredited programs in the U.S. The [[Master of Business Administration]] offered by the University is accredited by [[Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business]] (AACSB).{{cite web|url=https://www.aacsb.net/eweb/DynamicPage.aspx?Site=AACSB&WebKey=00E50DA9-8BB0-4A32-B7F7-0A92E98DF5C6 |title=Schools Accredited in Business – ordered by country/region, state, name|publisher=Aacsb|accessdate=27 October 2012}} ==Organization== ===Colleges=== ====College of Petroleum Engineering and Geosciences==== *Department of Petroleum Engineering, BSc, MS, PhD *Department of Geosciences, *Center of Integrative Petroleum Research ====College of Engineering Sciences and Applied Engineering==== {| |- |valign="top"| *Department of Aerospace Engineering: **[[Aerospace Engineering]] (AE): BSc, MSc *Department of Chemical Engineering: **[[Chemical Engineering]] (CHE): BSc, MSc, PhD *Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering: **[[Civil Engineering]] (CE): BSc, MSc, MEng, PhD *Department of Electrical Engineering: **[[Electrical Engineering]] (EE): BSc, MSc, PhD **Telecommunication (TELE): MSc *Department of Mechanical Engineering: **[[Mechanical Engineering]] (ME): BSc, MSc, PhD **[[Material Science|Material Science and Engineering]] (MSE): MSc |valign=" ====College of Computer Science & Engineering==== Contains{{cite web|title=CCSE Home Page|url=http://www.ccse.kfupm.edu.sa|publisher=KFUPM|accessdate=23 September 2012}} *Department of Computer Engineering: **[[Computer Engineering]] (COE): BSc, MSc **[[Computer Networks]] (CNW): MSc **Computer Science & Engineering (CSE): PhD (joint program with ICS) *Department of Information & Computer Science:{{cite web|title=Department of Information and Computer Science|url=http://www.kfupm.edu.sa/departments/ics/default.aspx#|publisher=KFUPM|accessdate=23 September 2012}} **[[Computer Science]] (CS): BSc, MSc **[[Software Engineering]] (SWE): BSc **Computer Science & Engineering (CSE): PhD (joint program with COE) *Department of Systems Engineering: **[[Industrial Engineering|Industrial & Systems Engineering]] (ISE): BSc, MSc **[[Control engineering|Control & Instrumentation Systems Engineering]] (CISE): BSc **[[Supply Chain Management]] (SCM): MSc **[[Systems Engineering]] (SE): MSc, PhD |} {| |- |valign="top"| ====College of Sciences==== *Department of Chemistry: **[[Chemistry]] (CHEM): BSc, MSc, PhD **[[Industrial Chemistry]] (ICHEM): BSc *Geosciences Department: **Geology (GEOL): B.Sc., M.Sc., Ph.D. **[[Geophysics]] (GEOP): BSc, MSc **[[Environmental Sciences]] (ENVS): MSc *Department of Mathematics & Statistics: **Mathematics (MATH): B.Sc., M.Sc., Ph.D. **Statistics (STAT): B.Sc. **[[Actuarial Science & Financial Mathematics]] (AS): BSc *Department of Physics: **[[Physics]] (PHYS): BSc, MSc, PhD **[[Medical Physics]] (MEPH): Master of Medical Physics. |valign="top"| ====College of Industrial Management (CIM)==== *Department of Accounting & Management Information Systems: **Accounting (ACCT): B.Sc. **[[Management Information Systems]] (MIS): BSc *Department of Finance & Economics: **Finance (FIN): B.Sc. *Department of Management & Marketing: **Marketing (MKT): B.Sc. **Management (MGT): B.Sc. *Master of Business Administration Program [[MBA]]: *[[Executive MBA]] Program: |} {| |- |valign="top"| ====College of Environmental Design (CED)==== *Department of Architecture: **Architecture (ARC): B.Sc. *Department of [[Architectural Engineering]] (ARE): **[[Architectural Engineering]] (ARE): BSc, MSc, M.Engg. *Department of City & Regional Planning: **[[City Planning]] (CP): BSc **[[City Planning|City & Regional Planning]]: MSc *Department of Construction, Engineering & Management: **[[Construction Management|Construction, Engineering & Management]]: MSc, M.Engg. **[[Engineering Management]]: M.Engg. |valign="top"| ====College of Applied and Supporting Studies (non-degree)==== *English Language Department (ENGL) *General Studies Department (GS) *Islamic & Arabic Studies Department (IAS) *Physical Education Department (PE) |valign="top"| ====Community colleges==== Additionally, there are two active and one defunct [[community college]]s: * [[Dammam Community College]]: [[Associate's Degree]]s in Accounting, Computer & Information Technology, Marketing, Human Resource Management, Safety Technology and Supply Chain Management. * [[Hafar Al-Batin]] Community College: [[Associate's Degree]]s in: **[[Business Administration]], **[[Office Administration]], **Computer Science & Engineering Technology, **[[Electronics Engineering Technology|Electrical & Electronics Engineering Technology]], **[[Mechanical Engineering Technology]], **[[Nondestructive testing|Non-destructive Evaluation Technology]] * [[Hail]] Community College (defunct), now [[University of Ha'il]] |} ===Other academic departments=== *Preparatory Year Program{{cite web|url=http://www.kfupm.edu.sa/pyp |title=Preparatory Year Program |publisher=Kfupm.edu.sa |date= |accessdate=27 October 2012}} *[[Continuing Education]] Department:[http://www.kfupm.edu.sa/shortcourses/ ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061212071256/http://www.kfupm.edu.sa/shortcourses/ |date=12 December 2006 }} The Department of Continuing Education Programs offers short courses. These courses are designed for engineers, managers, and practitioners who are interested in pursuing further studies in their fields. The courses are open to all applicants who have the desire and the background to participate. *University Diploma Programs{{cite web|url=http://www.kfupm.edu.sa/diploma/ |title=University Diploma Program|publisher=King Fahd University|accessdate=11 August 2012}} offers Diploma Degrees in Accounting, Computer Applications and Marketing. ===Rector=== The current Acting Rector of KFUPM is [[Dr. Sahel N. Abduljauwad]].{{cite web|url=http://www.kfupm.edu.sa/SitePages/en/rector.aspx|title=KFUPM Website}} ====Previous rectors of KFUPM==== * H.E. Dr. Khaled S. Al-Sultan * H.E. Dr. Saleh Ambah * H.E. Dr. Baker Bin Baker * H.E. Dr. Abdulaziz Al Dukhayyil ===International Advisory Board=== King Fahd University of Petroleum & Minerals organized the International Advisory Board (IAB) in March 2007. The IAB is composed of senior academic and corporate executives. ====IAB members==== {{Div col}} *[[Martin C. Jischke]]: Chairman International Advisory Board, President Emeritus, [[Purdue University]], [[Indiana]], United States *[[Khalid A. Al-Falih]]: Vice chairman International Advisory Board, chief executive officer, Saudi Arabian Oil Company ([[Saudi Aramco]]), Saudi Arabia{{cite web|url=http://www.saudiaramco.com/en/home.html#our-company%257C%252Fen%252Fhome%252Four-company%252Fleadership%252Fkhalid-a-al-falih.baseajax.html |title=Home |publisher=Saudi Aramco|date=1 August 2012|accessdate=11 August 2012}} *[[Khaled S. Al-Sultan]]: Ex-Rector of [[KFUPM]] and President of [[King Abdullah City for Atomic and Renewable Energy]] *[[Andrew Gould]]: Chairman and chief executive officer, [[Schlumberger|Schlumberger Limited]], U.S. *[[Shih Choon Fong]]: President of [[King Abdullah University of Science and Technology]], [[Thuwal]], Saudi Arabia; former president of the [[National University of Singapore]], Singapore *[[Mohamed Al-Mady]]: Vice chairman and chief executive officer, [[SABIC|Saudi Basic Industries Corporation]], Saudi Arabia[http://www.sabic.com/corporate/en/ourcompany/boardofdirectors/mohamed_h_ai_mady.aspx ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100706161706/http://www.sabic.com/corporate/en/ourcompany/boardofdirectors/mohamed_h_ai_mady.aspx |date=6 July 2010 }} *[[John Etchemendy]]: Provost of [[Stanford University]], California, U.S. *[[Hugo F. Sonnenschein]]: President Emeritus and Adam Smith Distinguished Service Professor, [[University of Chicago]], [[Illinois]], U.S. *[[John G. Rice]]: Vice chairman, [[General Electric]] and President and chief executive officer of [[GE Technology Infrastructure]], U.S.{{cite web|url=http://www.ge.com/company/leadership/bios_exec/john_rice.html |title=John Rice, President, CEO, GE Global Growth and Operations, Biography |publisher=GE |date=5 February 2008 |accessdate=11 August 2012}} *[[Charles Elachi]]: Director of [[NASA]]'s [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] (JPL), located in [[Pasadena, California]].{{cite web|url=http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/about/bio_elachi.cfm|title=Dr. Charles Elachi|publisher=NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory|accessdate=11 August 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120809012249/http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/about/bio_elachi.cfm|archivedate=9 August 2012|df=dmy-all}} *[[Olivier Appert]]: Chairman and chief executive officer [[Institut Francais du Petrole]] (IFP), France *[[Nam Pyo Suh]]: President of [[Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology]] (KAIST), [[South Korea]] *[[Wolfgang A. Herrmann]]: President, [[Technische Universitaet Muenchen]] (TUM), Germany *[[Henry Rosovsky]]: Lewis P and Linda L Geyser University Professor, Emeritus at [[Harvard University]], [[Massachusetts]], U.S. *[[Samir A. Al Baiyat]]: Secretary of International Advisory Board, and Manager of Research & Innovation Support at KFUPM {{Div col end}} ===King Abdullah Bin Abdulaziz Science Park=== Generally referred to as the KASP, the science park was established in 2002 and is located on a 35-hectare site north of the KFUPM campus. The park is closely integrated with the university. With its proximity to the science and engineering colleges, KASP provides interaction between tenant firms and their personnel and university scientists and engineers. At present, [[Schlumberger]],{{cite web|url=http://www.slb.com/about/rd/research/sdcr.aspx|title=Dhahran Carbonate Research Center, Schlumberger |publisher=Slb|accessdate=11 August 2012}} [[Ciba Specialty Chemicals|Ciba]], [[Yokogawa]],{{cite web|url=http://www.yokogawa.com/ioc/w-locations/ioc-w-locations-saudiarabia-en.htm |title=Saudi Arabia|publisher=Yokogawa|accessdate=11 August 2012}} [[Honeywell]],{{cite web|url=http://hpsweb.honeywell.com/Cultures/en-US/NewsEvents/NewsRoom/PressReleases/Dharan_PR_10252009.htm |title=Industrial Automation and Control Solutions from Honeywell|publisher=HPS|date=7 August 2012|accessdate=11 August 2012}} [[UOP LLC|UOP]], [[Baker Hughes]]{{cite web|url=http://www.bakerhughes.com/company/corporate-social-responsibility/people-and-society/talent-management/technology-and-education-centers/technology-centers/csr-dhahran-technology-center|title=CSR-Dhahran Technology Center|publisher=BakerHughes|accessdate=11 August 2012}} and [[JCCP]] have joined the park. ===Consulting Services Center=== The Consulting Services Center facilitate the consulting services for the university faculty to serve the industrial community in [[Saudi Arabia]] which contributes to their professional development and helps the outside community to resolve problems that require high intellectual and technological background.{{cn|date=June 2018}} ===Technology Business Incubator=== The Technology Business Incubator provides a set of logistical, strategic, and operational support for start-up Saudi technology companies and entrepreneurs. ===Liaison office=== The Liaison Office is a point of contact with the industry/business. ===Sultan bin AbdulAziz Science & Technology Center (SciTech)=== The center is at the corniche of nearby [[Khobar]] city on 21,700 m2. The buildings area is 14,100 m2. It consists of seven main show halls, dealing with different sciences and technologies. There are more than 350 scientific exhibited pieces and the [[IMAX]] scientific dome (the only [[IMAX]] theater in [[Saudi Arabia]]),{{cite web|url=http://www.scitech.com.sa/?PUrl=Pages&Page=Dome |title=مركز سلطان بن عبد العزيز للعلوم والتقنية |publisher=Scitech|accessdate=11 August 2012}} the Astronomic Observatory, Educational Unit, Conference Hall, Temporary Exhibitions Hall and Administrative and Services Facilities. ==Research== ===The Research Institute (RI)=== The technical expertise for applied research available in the RI is focused in its seven centers with their sections/labs. * '''Center for Applied Physical Sciences''': The Metrology and Standards Section and the Central Analytical Laboratory. * '''Center for Communications and Computer Research''': Computer Technology, and Communications Technology Sections. * '''Center for Economics and Management Systems''': Business Incubators, Economic Studies, and Management and Quality Control Sections. * '''Center for Engineering Research''': Materials, Urban Areas Engineering, Engineering Analysis, Energy Systems Sections, and Material Characterization Laboratory. * '''Center for Environment and Water''': Water, Environment, and Marine Studies Sections. * '''Center for Petroleum and Minerals''': Petroleum and Gas Engineering, Petroleum Geology and Geophysics, Minerals Resources, and Remote Sensing Sections. * '''Center for Refining and Petrochemicals''': Refining, Petrochemicals, and Petrochemical Products Development Sections. The manpower of the RI as of 1 January 2005 was 258 full-time employees, of whom 53 held PhD degrees, 64 held MS degrees, 50 held BS degrees, and 91 held other credentials. Project teams are typically formed of 35% full-time RI researchers, 25% faculty members, 10% students, and 30% support staff. === Library=== {{cite web|title=KFUPM Libraries|url=http://library.kfupm.edu.sa/|publisher=KFUPM|accessdate=23 September 2012}} The library, centrally located in Building 8 and a short walk from most classrooms and laboratories, has an available floor space of nearly 7,000 square meters. It is an "open-stack" library, allowing users free access to its resources. Reading areas are on the first, third, and fourth floors. The current collection of books and bound periodicals totals over 328,000 volumes, 32% in science, 21% in engineering, 24% in humanities, and 23% in social sciences. It has over 23,000 volumes in Arabic and over 300,000 volumes in English and subscribes to approximately 1,500 periodicals. In addition, there are some 490,000 research reports on microfiche and 63,000 documents in other media, including more than 25,000 educational films and 38,000 reels of journal back issues on microfilm. Audiovisual materials are provided through a well-equipped [[audio-visual]] (AV) department with a collection consisting principally of motion pictures, filmstrips, videotapes, and audio cassettes. These AV materials can be used in the library auditorium which is also used for seminars, lectures, short courses, theses defense, and other presentations.{{cn|date=June 2018}} ===Collaborations=== *Center for Clean Water and Clean Energy at MIT and KFUPM.{{cite web |url=http://engineering.mit.edu/research/labs_centers_programs/kfupm.php |title=MIT Engineering: Labs, Centers and Programs: King Fahd University of Petroleum and Minerals Program on Clean Water and Clean Energy |publisher=MIT |accessdate=27 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121027090355/http://engineering.mit.edu/research/labs_centers_programs/kfupm.php |archivedate=27 October 2012 |df=dmy-all }} === KFUPM Endowment === It was announced in 2007 that the University will establish an independent administrative body tasked with managing and overseeing donations and the University's industry collaboration activities. The Endowment Fund Office is composed of an independent governing board, with a professional staff that manages the Fund's operations, resembling those of Harvard Investment Group and the Yale Investment Office. The KFUPM Fund is the first in Saudi Arabia to be professionally managed by specialized finance and investment teams. The mission of the Fund is to be able to provide the necessary financing (up to 30%) the University needs in the future, and cover costs that aren't sponsored by the University's main funds source, The Ministry of Education. In just over five years, the Endowment has grown to be the largest university endowment in Saudi Arabia (relative to the size of KFUPM budget) and was able to raise more than $500 million in financial assets along with real estate assets.{{cite web|url=http://www3.kfupm.edu.sa/kfupmfund/Default.aspx#page/12|title=::: KFUPM Endowment :::|publisher=}} The Endowment's main investment projects include the establishment of a business park in the north side of the KFUPM campus that includes constructing numerous hotels and office buildings. The University has contracted the UK-based Marts & Lundy to consult on fundraising and managing activities.{{cite web|url=http://www3.kfupm.edu.sa/kfupmfund/News.aspx?nid=48|title=::: KFUPM Endowment :::|publisher=}} The Fund's main financing activities include the establishment of specific-purpose research grants and projects. In addition, the Endowment has announced the creation of 8 doctoral fellowships (the first of its kind in the kingdom that is unrelated to governmental constraints in terms of funding).{{cite web|url=http://www3.kfupm.edu.sa/kfupmfund/News.aspx?nid=47|title=::: KFUPM Endowment :::|publisher=}} ==Campus life== ===Students clubs=== {{colbegin}} *Cyclists Club *Book Club *Events Club *Community Service Club *Entrepreneurship Club *CIM Club *Fine Arts Club *Visitation Club *Media Club *Health & Fitness Club *Chess Club *Diving Club *Photography Club *[[International Society of Automation]] (ISA) KFUPM Student Chapter *Systems Engineering Club *CCSE Club (Computer Club) *Math Club *Chemistry Club *Physics Club *Earth Sciences Club *Graduate Studies Club *English Club *Innovation Club *Aerospace Engineering Club *Civil Engineering Club *College of Industrial Management Club *Chemical Engineering Club *Cultural Club *Electrical Engineering Club *Environmental Design Club *IEEE KFUPM Student Branch *IET KFUPM Student Branch{{cite web|url=http://iet.ikfupm.com|title=Celebrating Engineering!|publisher=KFUPM Young Members Section|accessdate=27 October 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120210172621/http://iet.ikfupm.com/|archivedate=10 February 2012|df=dmy-all}} *Jawala Club (Scouts) *Petroleum Engineering Club *Science Club *Social Club *SPE-KFUPM Student Chapter *Theater Club *Mechanical Engineering Club *Arabic Language Club *Photography Club *Microsoft Imagine Club, Student Chapter *Toastmasters Club {{colend}} ==KFUPM alumni== ===Government and public service=== * [[Abdulaziz bin Salman]], deputy petroleum and mineral resources minister (BSc and MBA, in industrial administration, '85) * [[Abdulaziz bin Majid]], former governor of Al [[Medina]] Al Monawwarah. * Eng. Abdullah bin AbdulRahman AlMogbel, Saudi minister of Transport and Former Mayor of Riyadh * [[Bandar bin Khalid Al Saud|Bandar bin Khalid Al Faisal]], chairman of [[Sama Airlines|Sama]] Airlines and member of [[Arab Thought Foundation]] [[Board of Trustees]] (BSc, Computer Science, '88) * [[Saud bin Khalid Al Saud|Saud bin Khalid Al Faisal]], deputy governor of [[Saudi Arabian General Investment Authority]] and president of National Competitiveness Center(NCC) (BSc, Finance '01) *[[Ghazi Mashal Ajil al-Yawer]], was [[President of Iraq]] under the [[Iraqi Interim Government]] after the [[2003 invasion of Iraq]]. * [[Fahd bin Abdul Rahman Balghunaim]], Saudi minister of agriculture since May 2003 (BSc, [[Civil Engineering]], '75) * [[Abdullatif bin Ahmed Al Othman]], current governor of [[Saudi Arabian General Investment Authority]] and former senior vice president of [[Saudi Aramco]] (BSc, [[Civil Engineering]], '79) ===Academics=== *[[Khaled S. Al-Sultan]], current rector of [[KFUPM]], (BSc and MSc, [[Systems Engineering]], '87) *[[Zaghloul El-Naggar]], a Muslim scholar and chairman of Committee of Scientific Notions in the [[Qur'an]], Supreme Council of Islamic Affairs, [[Cairo]], Egypt. El-Najjar worked as a Professor of Geology at KFUPM from 1979–1996{{cite web|url=http://www.irf.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=218%3Abio-data-zaghloul-al-najjar+&catid=57%3Aorators-international&Itemid=174 |title=Islamic Research Foundation – Dr. Zaghloul Al Najjar |publisher=Irf.net |date=17 November 1933 |accessdate=27 October 2012}} *[[Ali Abdullah Al-Daffa]], professor in field of [[History of Mathematics]]. *[[Abdul-Rahim Ahmad]], professor of [[Information Systems]] and [[Decision Sciences]] at the Faculty of Management, Dalhousie University, Canada. ===Oil and gas industry=== *[[Khalid A. Al-Falih]], president and CEO of [[Saudi Aramco]], earned [[M.B.A.]]in 1991.[https://web.archive.org/web/20110716010420/http://www.saudiaramco.com/irj/portal/anonymous?favlnk=%2FSaudiAramcoPublic%2Fdocs%2FAt%2BA%2BGlance%2FCorporate%2BManagement%2FKhalid%2BA.%2BAl-Falih&ln=en] *[[Nadhmi Al-Nasr]], former [[interim]] president of [[King Abdullah University of Science and Technology]] and [[Saudi Aramco]] Vice President of [[KAUST]] (BSc in [[Chemical Engineering]] '79).{{cite web|url=http://www.kaust.edu.sa/about/admin/senior/al-nasr.html|title=The University Executive Committee; Mr. Nadhmi A. Al.Naser|publisher=KAUST|accessdate=27 October 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120929000049/http://www.kaust.edu.sa/about/admin/senior/al-nasr.html|archivedate=29 September 2012|df=dmy-all}} *[[Kamal Al-Yahya]] Ph.D, geophysicist and senior VP in CGG. ===Sports and media=== *[[Yasser Al-Qahtani]], [[Saudi Arabian]] footballer ([[Dropping out|drop-out]]){{citation needed|date=December 2016}} ===Others=== *Mohammed Khaleel Ahmed, Transmission Planning Engineer, Saudi Electricity Company *Syed Zabiullah, Coating Engineer, Saudi Steel Pipe Company ==See also== * [[List of things named after Saudi Kings]] ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=33em}} ==External links== * {{Official website|1=http://www.kfupm.edu.sa}} {{Coord|26|18|35|N|50|08|38|E|type:edu_source:placeopedia|display=title}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{DEFAULTSORT:King Fahd University Of Petroleum And Minerals}} [[Category:Dhahran]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1963]] [[Category:Universities and colleges in Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:King Fahd University of Petroleum and Minerals| ]] [[Category:1963 establishments in Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:Energy education]]

The '''knowledge divide''' is the gap in standards of living between those who can find, create, manage, process, and disseminate information or knowledge, and those who are impaired in this process. According to a 2005 UNESCO World Report, the rise in the 21st century of a global information society has resulted in the emergence of knowledge as a valuable resource, increasingly determining who has access to power and profit.<ref>UNESCO World Report: Toward Knowledge Societies (Paris: UNESCO, 2005), 158-159.</ref> The rapid dissemination of information on a potentially global scale as a result of new information media<ref>UNESCO 2005, 160.</ref> and the globally uneven ability to assimilate knowledge and information has resulted in potentially expanding gaps in knowledge between individuals and nations.<ref>Joseph Stiglitz, "Knowledge as a Global Public Good," in Global Public Goods: International Cooperation in the 21st Century, ed. I. Kahl et al. (Oxford University Press, 1999), 318.</ref>
==Introduction==
In the 21st century, the emergence of the [[knowledge society]] becomes pervasive.<ref>[[UNESCO]] World Report (2005) Towards Knowledge Societies; retrieved from http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0014/001418/141843e.pdf</ref> The transformations of world's economy and of each society have a fast pace. Together with information and communication technologies ([[Information technology|ICT]]) these new paradigms have the power to reshape the global economy.<ref>Information Society Commission (2002). Building the Knowledge Society - Report to Government, December 2002 retrieved from http://www.isc.ie/downloads/know.pdf</ref> In order to keep pace with innovations, to come up with new ideas, people need to produce and manage knowledge. This is why knowledge has become essential for all societies.
==Between nations==
According to [[UNESCO]] and the [[World Bank]],<ref>World Bank World Development Report: Knowledge for Development (New York: Oxford University Press, 1999).</ref> knowledge gaps between nations may occur due to the varying degrees by which individual nations incorporate the following elements:
* ''Human rights and fundamental freedoms'': An absence of freedom within a society can diminish or delay the ability of its members to acquire, debate, and transmit knowledge. Vital to the spread of knowledge and information between nations are such freedoms as [[freedom of expression]], an absence of censorship, free circulation of information, and [[freedom of the press]].<ref>UNESCO 2005, 28.</ref> * ''[[Democracy]]'' * ''Plurality of knowledge and information'': This includes a diverse media<ref>UNESCO 2005, 28.</ref> and the acceptance of diverse forms of knowledge.<ref>UNESCO 2005, 60.</ref> * ''Quality infrastructure'': For instance, a poor electrical grid makes the existence of computer networks or of higher education institutions less attainable. * ''Effective communication system'': This will affect the dissemination of knowledge or movement of ideas within and between nations.<ref>Stiglitz, 317-318.</ref> * ''Effective education system'': Gaps in knowledge between nations can exist when individual countries invest too little in primary school education, which acts as the base for the entire education system.<ref>Stiglitz, 317.</ref> According to [[UNESCO]], in order for a nation to become a knowledge society, primary education must focus on basic literacy and must be universally accessible.<ref>UNESCO 2005, 72.</ref> However, as others have pointed out, higher education may be equally important for closing knowledge gaps between nations, particularly between newly industrialized nations, such as the Republic of Korea, and more advanced industrial societies.<ref>Stiglitz, 317.</ref> For the former, higher education can play an important role in bridging knowledge gaps, but must benefit more than a small elite portion of the population and must be taught at international standards.<ref>Stiglitz, 317.</ref> The poor development of educational institutions from a society affects the creativity of people belonging to that society. * ''Focus on Research and Innovation'': As the [[World Bank]] suggests, [[Research & Development]] within a nation can enable it to follow current developments in global knowledge and also to understand how to adapt external knowledge and technology to meet its needs.<ref>World Bank World Development Report, 1999, 36.</ref> In nations with low degrees of R&D, government funding can provide a significant portion of support that can later be taken over by private investment.<ref>World Bank World Development Report, 1999, 36.</ref> Closely tied to effective education systems is the need for a nation to allow for academic freedom.<ref>UNESCO 2005, 96.</ref> Because higher educational institutions are significant contributors to R&D,<ref>World Bank World Development Report 1999, 36.</ref> these institutions must be granted freedom to create and disseminate knowledge.<ref>UNESCO 2005, 28.</ref> An environment supportive of research and innovation may also help stem the "[[brain drain]]" of educated individuals from knowledge-poor nations to knowledge-rich nations.<ref>UNESCO 2005, 160.</ref> * ''Intellectual Property Rights'': Closely connected to a focus on research and innovation are national and international Intellectual Property Rights. Within a nation, Intellectual Property Rights can spawn research and innovation by providing economic incentives for investing in new knowledge development.<ref>Stiglitz, 311.</ref> However, as stated by the [[World Bank]], by protecting innovations, intellectual property rights may also inhibit knowledge-sharing and may prevent developing nations from benefitting from knowledge produced in other countries.<ref>World Bank World Development Report 1999, 34.</ref>
==Digital divide==
The information and ICT systems that support knowledge are very important. This is why digitization is viewed closely related to knowledge. Scientists generally agree that there is a [[digital divide]], recently different reports also showed the existence of knowledge divide.<ref>Information Society Commission, 2002; UNESCO, 2005</ref>
The creation and effective use of knowledge are increasingly related to the development of an ICT infrastructure. Without ICT, it is impossible to have an infrastructure able to process the huge flow of information required in an advanced economy. In particular, without adequate technical support, it is difficult to develop and use e-learning and electronic documents to overcome time and space constraints.
The digital divide is, however, but one important part of the larger knowledge divide. As UNESCO states, "closing the digital divide will not suffice to close the knowledge divide, for access to useful, relevant knowledge is more than simply a matter of infrastructure—it depends on training, cognitive skills and regulatory frameworks geared towards access to contents."<ref>UNESCO 2005, 22.</ref>
=== Criticism ===
In the book Digital Dead End, Virginia Eubanks criticizes the way that the digital divide is generally thought of as a division between haves and have-nots, where the solution is distribution. This over simplistic depiction obscures the fact that often social and [[structural inequality]] is at the root of the divide. According to a study done by Eubanks with women of the YWCA, the women of the community "insisted that have-nots possess many different kinds of crucial information and skills." In other words, it is not simply knowledge of the technology itself that is the issue but the structural system based on perpetuating the status quo in which the haves "hoard" knowledge.<ref>Eubanks, V. (2011). Digital dead end: fighting for social justice in the information age. MIT Press.</ref>
==In gender, race, ethnicity and social class==
First, it was noticed that a great difference exists between the [[North-South divide|North and the South]] {{Where|date=July 2011}} (rich countries vs. poor countries). The development of knowledge depends on spreading Internet and computer technology and also on the development of education in these countries. If a country has attained a higher literacy level then this will result in having higher level of knowledge. Indeed, UNESCO's report details many social issues in knowledge divide related to globalization. There was noticed a knowledge divide with respect to * Gender: Socio-cultural inequalities between men and women, such as unequal access to education and technology, create the conditions for unequal access to knowledge. This can cause significant knowledge gaps both within and between nations, the latter resulting from individual nations' underutilization of their full knowledge workforce.<ref>UNESCO World Report 2005, 167-168.</ref> * Race * Ethnicity * Social class
==See also== * [[Digital citizen]] * [[Knowledge]] * [[Knowledge gap hypothesis]]
==Notes== {{reflist|1}}

Computers & Education, 40, 327–342.([http://innovations.oise.utoronto.ca/~jhewitt/ctl1603/papers/Hakkarainen%20&%20Palonen%202003.pdf]) *Scardamalia, M. (2003). Crossing the digital divide: Literacy as by-product of knowledge building. Journal of Distance Education, 17 (Suppl. 3, Learning Technology Innovation in Canada), 78-81. ([http://ikit.org/fulltext/2003_Crossing.htm]) *Scardamalia, M., & Bereiter, C. (2003). Knowledge building environments: Extending the limits of the possible in education and knowledge work. In A. DiStefano, K. E. Rudestam, & R. Silverman (Eds.), Encyclopedia of distributed learning (pp. 269–272). Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage Publications. ([http://ikit.org/fulltext/2003_KBE.pdf]) *The K-Village Project. www.k-village.org ([http://www.k-village.org])
==External links== * http://www.knowledge-divide.org Research Project "The changing knowledge divide in the global economy"
